body:
I'm looking into this issue and I'm surprised to see what NUnit is trying to do here. I imagine this was done a long time ago but honestly I don't see any reason why NUnit would want to intercept logs coming from log4net, or at least, the way to do it properly is hardly without any side effects. If I understand the issue correctly what is happening is that NUnit is overwriting the log4net configuration done by the code under test thus preventing the code from logging where it intended to.

I'm not sure how to proceed, except that I don't see a bulletproof solution and would rather propose to invert the dependency. Rather than NUnit trying to intercept logs coming from the code under test I would expose an appender that the code under test could configure and use during the tests.

Unfortunately this would most likely require NUnit to reference log4net, which is certainly not something we want to do in the framework (or anywhere else), except perhaps some sort of addin, as @CharliePoole mentioned in the launchpad issue.

Thoughts?

As originally implemented, NUnit was adding it's own listener to the
configuration and displaying log4net output in the gui without stopping any
ongoing logging. However, that may have changed at some point so that it
now overwrites it.

I like your idea that we should simply provide an appender that sends the
text to NUnit... but for now, I'm in favor of removing the log4net
infrastructure from NUnit - certainly from the framework.

Charlie

I'm in favor of removing the current implementation but I think this
deserves some more discussion. Apologies for my ignorance here but I really
never got around to understand how NUnit captures log outputs.
As a user I would expect that any calls that I do to Console methods end up
in the test output. I am assuming this is not what is happening, right? In
that case, is there a reason why NUnit does not capture process
stdo/stderr? If this happened, using log4net rather than Console methods
for a user would be just a matter of configuring a console appender without
NUnit knowing anything about log4net and the user knowing nothing about how
NUnit reports test output.

This would be the best solution in my opinion, but I guess this is not what
is happening now, so I'd be curious to know why.

The NUnit Gui can selectively capture stdout, stderr, Trace and log4net
logs. It can display them in one or more output tabs, which is probably
overly complex. Each of these is captured using different approaches.

With stdout and stderr, the output goes to NUnit _instead_ of to the
console, since  the gui runner has no console. When the console runner is
used, we simply don't capture them.

For Trace and log4net, it's supposed to display in the Gui tab
_in_addition_to_ wherever else it displays. The original intent was that
the log capture would be extended to NLog and other 3rd party logging apps.

I don't know what the app is actually doing - this is an unconfirmed bug
report.

Charlie

Ok so if the GUI is capturing stdo/err (doesn't apply here as we don't have a GUI for 3.0 yet) and Console is doing nothing (what about the cases when the agent is involved? is out/err redirected?) I imagine that using a ConsoleAppender in a user's test assembly configuration is all it would take to capture log4net logs. I'll try to see if this is the case with the console runner before removing the log4net stuff from the framework and close this issue.

A bit more history: In the past, the console also captured the output. I
removed that and just let it go to console, leading to a bug report. Turns
out we needed to capture it anyway so that any EventListener addins could
process the output event. Now that we don't have addins, we don't need to
capture it at all.

I didn't remove the "hooks" for capturing output because I assumed we would
need it for the Gui. That may still be true for console output, but it
seems to me that any log4net output, if it got captured at all, should be
handled by the engine.

If possible I think we should stay away from trying to capture any logging framework's output. It should be the other way around: the user configures log4net with a ConsoleAppender because intuitively he expects that stdo/err are not touched in any way by NUnit and hence logs done with such an appender will appear in the output of the test, that's what I would expect at least.

I agree... let's aim toward that. Meanwhile, we can simplify the framework.

issue.title: Issue 13
issue.body:
Work on this issue is not complete, but I'm putting it on pause while I work on the issue of text capture, which came up while working on this one. Meanwhile, I'd like to merge the parts that are complete.

What's done:
1. Option --output is a synonym for --out, as for nunit-console and test-harness.
2. Option --err is implemented for redirecting error output
3. Option --work is implemented, but currently only affects where standard and error output go, since I have not yet implemented the changes to --explore and --result.
4. Option --timeout is implemented.
5. Option --teamcity is implemented - @simoneb please look at this
6. NUnitLite uses Off/On/All for labels but doesn't actually implement On correctly because of the capture issue. In fact, this is exactly what console and harness are currently doing.

One possibility, given the ramifications of the text capture issue, might be to back out item 6 and go back to a boolean option in all programs. My sense is that we'll save time by waiting to make any further changes.
